useStmt.citReq:
Publications and research reports based on the IPUMS-PMA database must cite it appropriately. The citation should include the following:
Elizabeth Heger Boyle, Devon Kristiansen, and Matthew Sobek. IPUMS-PMA: Version 1.0 [dataset] Minneapolis, MN: IPUMS, 2018. https://doi.org/10.18128/D081.V1.0
The licensing agreement for use of IPUMS-PMA data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography at http://bibliography.ipums.org/.
useStmt.conditions:
Users of IPUMS-PMA data must agree to abide by the conditions of use. A user's license is valid for one year and may be renewed. Users must agree to the following conditions:
(1) No fees may be charged for use or distribution of the data.
(2) Cite IPUMS appropriately. For information on proper citation, refer to the citation requirement section of this DDI document.
(3) Tell us about any work you do using the IPUMS. Publications, research reports, or presentations making use of IPUMS-PMA should be added to our Bibliography. Continued funding for the IPUMS depends on our ability to show our sponsor agencies that researchers are using the data for productive purposes.
(4) The IPUMS cannot be used for genealogical research
(5) It is difficult to use the IPUMS to study small geographic areas. In the IPUMS census samples for years 1940-present, no places having a population of fewer than 100,000 persons can be identified.
(6) Use it for GOOD -- never for EVIL.
(7) Please notify ipums@umn.edu regarding errors in the data or documentation.
useStmt.disclaimer: The user of the data acknowledges that the original collector of the data, the authorized distributor of the data, and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences based upon such uses.

fileTxt.filePlac: IPUMS, 50 Willey Hall, 225 - 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55455

var.name: SAMPLE
var.txt: SAMPLE is an IPUMS-generated variable that identifies the PMA sample from which the record is drawn. In some countries and years, PMA conducts more than one round of the survey. The data from each round are separately identified. In some cases, data from the same country and same round might have been split into more than one file according to geographic region.

catgry.labl: Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2019 Baseline
Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2020 Client Exit Interview
Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2020 COVID-19 Survey
Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2020 Phase 2
Ethiopia 2016/7 Maternal and Newborn Health Round 1
Nigeria (Kano and Lagos) 2019 Client Exit Interview

var.name: COUNTRY
var.txt: COUNTRY reports the country where the survey was fielded.

var.name: YEAR
var.txt: YEAR reports the year when the survey was fielded. Some interviews may have occurred early in the following year. YEAR does not reflect individual interview years.

var.name: PHASE
var.txt: PHASE reports the survey round within a given country for longitudinal samples. Phase 1 is the baseline sample, or the first observation of the panel, and additional phases are follow up surveys.

var.name: HHID
var.txt:
HHID is an IPUMS-constructed variable that uniquely identifies households. HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID number (EAID), a count variable starting from one corresponding to each value of HHIDORIG, year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
For cases where HHIDORIG is missing, HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID (EAID), household structure number (STRUCTURNO), household number within structure (HHNUM), year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
HHID does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one round of survey of PMA.
A different construction is used for cases in which STRUCTURNO and/or HHNUM are missing, or if EAID is not available. See the Comparability tab for more details.
var.codInstr: This is a 27-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: PERSONID
var.txt: PERSONID is an IPUMS-constructed variable that uniquely identifies individuals in household and female files across all samples. PERSONID is a concatenation of the IPUMS-constructed variable HHID, a variable that uniquely identifies households, and LINENO, which is the person's reference number within the household.
var.codInstr: This is a 33-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: RESPONDENT
var.txt: RESPONDENT indicates whether the person was the respondent to the household questionnaire. The household respondent reported information about the assets, access to water, and other information about the household, including the roster of household members.

var.name: ELIGIBLE
var.txt: ELIGIBLE identifies women aged 15 to 49 who were eligible to answer the female questionnaire. It is possible to have multiple eligible women in the same household, or no eligible women in the household.

var.name: LINENO
var.txt: LINENO is an IPUMS-constructed technical variable that numbers all persons within each household according to their order in the original data. The variable LINEORIG reports the original line number of a household member. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.

var.name: STRUCTURNO
var.txt:
STRUCTURNO is the number assigned by PMA2020 to the physical structure in which the household lives. The variable HHNUM reports the number of the dwelling within the structure in which the interviewed household lives.
This variable may include non-integer values in select samples. These values were not edited by IPUMS and are from the original data.
var.codInstr:
This is a numeric variable that represents structure where the household lives, except for the following code:
999998 = No response or missing

var.name: HHNUM
var.txt: HHNUM is the number assigned to the household's dwelling within a given structure (STRUCTURNO). There can be multiple dwellings within one structure, such as individual apartments (dwellings) in an apartment building (a structure). Households are defined as a group of people who live and eat together in the same dwelling.
var.codInstr: This is a 5-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: EAID
var.txt:
EAID reports the geographic enumeration area where the respondent was located. The EAID is the primary sampling unit for IPUMS PMA. Due to privacy concerns, the borders of these enumeration areas are not publicly available and the enumeration area is specified via an assigned number rather than a recognized name for a locale.
Enumeration areas do not cover all areas within each survey country. After 5 survey rounds using the same enumeration areas, PMA identifies new enumeration areas. Due to this sampling design, some households, eligible women respondents, or service delivery points might be selected to be interviewed in more than one survey within a 5 year period. The variables PREVINTERVIEWHQ, PREVINTERVIEWFQ, and PREVINTERVIEWSQ identifies household, female, and service delivery point respondents, respectively, who have been interviewed for PMA in a previous round. It is not possible, however, to link survey records for the same person between rounds.
var.codInstr: This is a numeric variable that represents a primary sampling unit identifier.

var.name: ENUMID
var.txt: ENUMID is a randomly-generated number that identifies the enumerator who administered the survey.
var.codInstr:
This variable represents a random identifier assigned to an enumerator except for the following codes:
99996 = Not interviewed (household questionnaire) 99998 = No response or missing

var.name: CONSENTFQ
var.labl: Female respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent to the female questionnaire completed the survey. The variable RESULTFQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: AVAILABLEFQ
var.labl: Female respondent present and available to be interviewed
var.txt: AVAILABLEFQ indicates whether the woman who was eligible for the survey was present and available to be interviewed for the female questionnaire.

var.name: FQACQUAINTED
var.labl: How well acquainted with the respondent
var.txt:
FQACQUAINTED indicates to what extent the interviewer was acquainted with the female questionnaire respondent. PMA2020 surveys were fielded by resident enumerators, meaning that the interviewers lived in or near the enumeration areas they surveyed.
The PMA2020 team used this variable to investigate the effect of the level of acquaintance with the resident enumerator on the answers given by female respondents, especially about sensitive issues such as use of contraception. See the methodological report for more details.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMFQ
var.txt:
VISITNUMFQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the female respondent in the household in order to complete the female questionnaire interview. Up to three visits were made for each female questionnaire respondent.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: RESULTFQ
var.txt: RESULTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent completed the female questionnaire and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: CROSS_SECTION
var.labl: Observation is in the cross-sectional sample
var.txt: CROSS_SECTION indicates whether the person was included in the cross sectional sample for that year. If the person was not in the cross sectional sample, they were exclusively in the longitudinal sample. All persons in the cross sectional sample were also included in the longitudinal sample. See our sample notes on longitudinal data for more information.

var.name: INTFQMON
var.txt: INTFQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The year of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQYEAR.

var.name: INTFQYEAR
var.txt: INTFQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The month of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQMON.

var.name: FQINSTID
var.txt: FQINSTID is a constructed variable that uniquely identifies each respondent to the female questionnaire across all PMA samples. If a woman was interviewed in multiple rounds of PMA, FQINSTID cannot be used to link the same woman between samples because a new value for FQINSTID is generated for each "instance" of a woman's interview.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: CONSENTHQ
var.labl: Household respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTHQ indicates whether or not the respondent for the household survey consented to be interviewed and completed the survey. The variable RESULTHQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: AVAILABLEHQ
var.labl: Household respondent present and available at least once
var.txt: AVAILABLEHQ indicates whether a member of the household was available to be interviewed. This is recorded by the interviewer prior to beginning the household questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMHQ
var.txt:
VISITNUMHQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the household to reach the household respondent. Enumerators would visit up to three times.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: RESULTHQ
var.txt: RESULTHQ indicates whether the household questionnaire was completed and, if not, why not. For example, the household survey could not be completed if the household members refused to participate in the survey, if they were not at home during repeated visits, or if the dwelling was destroyed and uninhabited.

var.name: INTHQMON
var.txt: INTHQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The year of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQYEAR.

var.name: INTHQYEAR
var.txt: INTHQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The month of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQMON.

var.name: HHIDORIG
var.txt:
HHIDORIG reports the household identification code from the original data assigned by PMA. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters.
IPUMS has generated its own household identification number HHID.
HHIDORIG does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one survey round of PMA.

var.name: PERSONIDORIG
var.txt: PERSONIDORIG is the original person identification code assigned by PMA2020. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters with the person's line number within the household concatenated onto the end.

var.name: LINEORIG
var.txt: LINEORIG is a technical variable that numbers all persons within each household. The related variable LINENO is an IPUMS-generated line number of a household member according to their order in the original data. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.
var.codInstr: LINEORIG is a 2-digit numeric variable that represents the household member's line number within the household in the original data.

var.name: SURVEYWILLING
var.labl: Willing to participate in another survey
var.txt:
SURVEYWILLING indicates whether the woman would be willing to participate in another survey on this or any other topic either by phone or in person at some point in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COUNTRYSTR
var.txt: COUNTRYSTR reports the country where the survey was fielded. The codes assigned to each country are the alpha-2 codes (a two-character string) used by the UN Statistics Division and the ISO (International Organization for Standardization).
var.codInstr:
This variable is a 2-letter variable that takes the following values:
BF = Burkina Faso CD = Congo, Democratic Republic CI = Cote d'Ivoire ET = Ethiopia GH = Ghana ID = Indonesia IN = India KE = Kenya NE = Niger NG = Nigeria UG = Uganda

var.name: FQWEIGHT
var.txt:
FQWEIGHT is a nationally representative inverse probability weight for respondents of the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT should be used in analyses of all questions on the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT controls for female non-response, but because all eligible females in the household responded to the questionnaire, respondent selection probability does not need to be controlled for. For more details on how FQWEIGHT was calculated, please see the Weighting Memo from the PMA team.
For person records who were not women aged 15 to 49, the value of FQWEIGHT is zero.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: STRATA
var.txt:
STRATA defines the stratification for each sample. Some countries use only urban/rural stratification, others use regions, and some use both levels of stratification. Users may use STRATA and EAID (the primary sampling unit) to adjust sampling errors to account for sampling design of IPUMS-PMA samples.
For more information on sample design for IPUMS-PMA surveys, see the sampling design memo for households and women.

var.name: EAWEIGHT
var.txt: EAWEIGHT is a component of the final estimation weights. It represents the likelihood of the enumeration area being selected for sampling.
var.codInstr: This variable is a numeric variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: SUBNATIONAL
var.txt: SUBNATIONAL identifies the subnational region where the respondent was located. This variable includes regions for all countries surveyed in PMA.

var.name: URBAN
var.txt: URBAN indicates whether the respondent was located in a place designated as urban or as rural. Urban/rural status varies across countries, depending on the definition of the country's statistical bureau.

var.name: GEOBF
var.txt: GEOBF reports the region of Burkina Faso in which the respondent was located.

var.name: GEOCD
var.txt: GEOCD reports the province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in which the respondent was located.

var.name: GEOCI
var.txt:
GEOCI reports the region of Cote d'Ivoire in which the respondent was located.
When using the GIS boundary shapefiles provided by IPUMS PMA, regions not included in this variable are coded as 99.

var.name: GEOKE
var.txt:
GEOKE reports the county of Kenya in which the respondent was located.
When using the GIS boundary shapefiles provided by IPUMS PMA, counties not included in this variable are coded as 99.

var.name: GEOUG
var.txt: GEOUG reports the region of Uganda where the respondent was located with the additional detail that was added starting in 2020 samples. Please see GEOUGGEN and GEOUGDET for similar variables with wider availability and larger geographic ranges.

var.name: AGE
var.txt:
AGE reports the woman's age at her last birthday as reported by the woman herself. AGE may differ from the woman's age as reported by the respondent of the household questionnaire (AGEHQ). When AGE and AGEHQ differ, AGE is usually the more accurate measure since people are more likely to know their own exact age than the ages of other people.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, this question was included in the female screening questionnaire.

var.name: BIRTHMO
var.txt:
BIRTHMO reports the woman's birth month, as reported by the woman. Month of birth is recorded using the Gregorian calendar.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year for her date of birth, but not a month, January was the default month for BIRTHMO.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question associated with this variable was included in the female screening questionnaire.

var.name: BIRTHYR
var.txt:
BIRTHYR reports the year the respondent was born. Year of birth is recorded using the Gregorian calendar.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question associated with this variable was included in the female screening questionnaire.

var.name: DOBCMC
var.txt:
DOBCMC reports the century month code (CMC) for the month and year of the woman's birthdate.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see BIRTHMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for her birthdate, January was the default month. Also due to the data entry format, if a woman skipped the question, the default date was January 1st, 2021. IPUMS has recoded these latter cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result, in the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREGNANT
var.txt:
PREGNANT indicates whether or not the woman was pregnant at the time of the interview.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: DURCURPREG
var.txt:
DURCURPREG reports the duration of the woman's pregnancy in months completed.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, this question was included in the female screening questionnaire.

var.name: EDUCATT
var.labl: Highest level of school attended, detailed (18 categories)
var.txt:
EDUCATT reports the highest level of education the woman attended. It does not record whether the woman completed that level.
Countries differ in their educational systems and levels, but EDUCATT harmonizes codes across samples using composite coding. The first digit organizes education levels into the following broad, comparable categories: Never attended, primary school, post-primary, secondary school, post-secondary, and tertiary completed. The second digit preserves country-specific detail within these broad categories. For more details about the specific wording of education levels in each country's questionnaire, see questionnaire text for details.
The variable EDUCATTGEN is a recode of EDUCATT that reduces the coding scheme to four general categories.
The variable EDUCOMP provides additional information that was collected in the Democratic Republic of the Congo 2014 Round 2 sample regarding whether or not the woman had completed the highest level of schooling she had attended.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, this question was included in the 7-day followup questionnaire.

var.name: EDUCATTGEN
var.labl: Highest level of school attended, general (4 categories)
var.txt:
EDUCATTGEN reports the highest level of education the woman attended in four general categories. It does not report whether the woman completed that level.
Countries differ in their educational systems and levels, but EDUCATTGEN harmonizes the codes into a few general and largely comparable categories. Country-specific categories are retained in the variable EDUCATT.
The variable EDUCOMP provides additional information that was collected in the Democratic Republic of the Congo 2014 Round 2 sample regarding whether or not the woman had completed the highest level of schooling she had attended.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, this question was included in the 7-day followup questionnaire.

var.name: INTRAINING
var.txt:
For women aged 15-24 who are not currently attending school, INTRAINING reports whether the woman is currently enrolled in any training program.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: YRSCHL
var.labl: Highest grade / year of school completed
var.txt:
YRSCHL indicates the highest grade, form, standard, or year of school that the woman completed. Note that respondents did not respond in a standard way. Some respondents reported the last calendar year they attended school, others reported the total years of schooling they attended, and some reported the grade relative to the level of education.
For example, in a country with an 8-4-4 education system, a value of 4 in YRSCHL may be the same as a value of 12 for women who have attended secondary school. Conversely, two women may report the value of 3, but it may mean 3rd grade in primary school or three years of college. It is recommended that you use the variable EDUCATT for more clarification.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: EDUCLEFTAGE
var.labl: Age finished or dropped out of school
var.txt:
EDUCLEFTAGE reports the age of the woman when she finished or dropped out of school.
This question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: MARSTAT
var.txt:
MARSTAT reports the marital status of the respondent of the female questionnaire. Note that for some women who responded to the female questionnaire, MARSTAT might differ from the marital status reported in the household roster (MARSTATHQ), which might have been reported by a fellow household member. Because MARSTAT is reported directly by the individual, it is likely to be more accurate in cases of conflict between MARSTAT and MARSTATHQ.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question associated with this variable was included in the household screening questionnaire.

var.name: MARNUM
var.labl: Number of times married / lived with man as if married
var.txt:
MARNUM reports the number of times the woman has been married or lived with a man as if married.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PARTNEREV
var.txt:
PARTNEREV reports whether the woman has ever had a partner / boyfriend.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PTR1STAGE
var.labl: Age at time of first partner / boyfriend
var.txt:
For women aged 15-19 who have ever been married, had a partner / boyfriend, or are currently living with a man, PTR1STAGE indicates the woman's self-reported age at the time of her first partner / boyfriend.
PTR1STAGE has not been logically edited to remove unusually low values, which were present in the original data.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: RELATIONSHIP
var.txt:
For women who are not currently married or living with a man, RELATIONSHIP reports whether the woman is currently in a relationship.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: WIVESOTH
var.txt:
WIVESOTH indicates whether the woman's husband/partner has other wives or lives with other women as if married.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHAB1STSTARTMO
var.labl: Month started living with first husband or partner
var.txt:
For women who have been married more than once, COHAB1STSTARTMO reports the calendar month the woman started living with her first husband or partner.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when the woman started living with her first husband or partner, January was the default month for COHAB1STSTARTMO.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing."
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHAB1STSTARTYR
var.labl: Year started living with first husband or partner
var.txt:
For women who have been married more than once, COHAB1STSTARTYR reports the calendar year the respondent started living with her first husband or partner.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing."
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHABLASTSTARTMO
var.labl: Month started living with current or most recent husband or partner
var.txt:
COHABLASTSTARTMO reports the month the woman started living with her current or most recent husband or partner.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started living with her current or most recent husband or partner, January is the default month for COHABLASTSTARTMO.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing".
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHABLASTSTARTYR
var.labl: Year started living with current or most recent husband or partner
var.txt:
COHABLASTSTARTYR reports the year the respondent started living with her current or most recent husband or partner.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing".
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHAB1STSTARTCMC
var.labl: Date started living with first husband or partner in century month
var.txt:
For women who have been married more than once, COHAB1STSTARTCMC reports the century month code (CMC) for when the respondent started living with her first husband or partner.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see COHAB1STSTARTMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started living with her first husband or partner, January was the default month.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result, using the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COHABLASTSTARTCMC
var.labl: Date started living with current or most recent husband or partner in century month
var.txt:
COHABLASTSTARTCMC reports the century month code (CMC) for when the respondent started living with her current or most recent husband or partner.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see COHABLASTSTARTMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started living with her current or most recent husband or partner, January was the default month.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result, using the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: LANGUAGEFQ
var.labl: Language in which female interview was conducted
var.txt:
LANGUAGEFQ reports the language in which the female interview was conducted.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: MARDECIDE
var.txt:
MARDECIDE reports the woman's own level of involvement in the decision to marry.
This question associate with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: MARWILLDECIDE
var.labl: Plan to be involved in decision to marry
var.txt:
MARWILLDECIDE reports the extent to which the woman plans to be involved in the decision about her own marriage.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: NIGHTAWAYNUM
var.labl: The number of nights in the last 12 months that a woman has slept away from her community
var.txt:
For women aged 15-49, NIGHTAWAYNUM reports the number of nights she slept away from her community in the last 12 months.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: NIGHTHUSAWAYNUM
var.labl: The number of nights in the last 12 months that a woman's husband has slept away
var.txt:
For women aged 15-49 who are currently married or living with a man, NIGHTHUSAWAYNUM reports the number of nights her husband slept away from her community in the last 12 months.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: WEALTHQ
var.txt:
For all households with complete survey results, WEALTHQ refers to the relative wealth of the household where the woman lives, divided into quintiles from the poorest (Lowest quintile) to the richest (Highest quintile). Wealth is determined by a constructed wealth score (SCORE).  SCORE is a constructed variable that combines information on household assets, livestock owned, floor, roof, and wall construction materials, water sources, and toilet facilities to create a total wealth score for the household.
Household assets include possessions such as radios, televisions, bicycles, furniture, etc. These options may vary slightly by country and survey year.
Livestock counted are chickens, sheep, goats, horses/camels, cows/bulls, and local cattle. These options may vary slightly by country and survey year.
Floor materials are divided into three categories: natural materials (e.g. earth or dung), rudimentary materials (e.g. planks or palm bamboo), and finished materials (e.g. vinyl, ceramic tiles, cement, or carpet). These options may vary slightly by country and survey year.
Roof materials are divided into three categories: natural materials (e.g. a thatched roof or dung/mud), rudimentary materials (e.g. corrugated iron or tin cans), and finished materials (e.g. asbestos, concrete, or tiles). These options may vary slightly by country and survey year.
Wall materials are divided into three categories: natural materials (e.g. no walls, cane, or dung/mud), rudimentary materials (e.g. bamboo and mud, plywood, cardboard, or reused wood), and finished materials (e.g. cement, bricks, or wood planks with shingles). These options may vary slightly by country and survey year.
Water source includes options such as water piped into the dwelling, a public tap, a dug well, and others.
Toilet facility includes options such as a piped sewer system, composting toilet, etc. Unweighted means and standard deviations for each of the indicator variables are then used in a principal components analysis to determine the overall household wealth score.
The questions associated with this variable were included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: ROOF
var.txt:
ROOF reports the main material of the roof of the household. This variable is based on the interviewer's observation, not the interviewee's response.
The type of roof found in the household is used to calculate a wealth index based on the household's cumulative living standard. This information can be found in the variables SCORE, WEALTHQ, and WEALTHT.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: FLOOR
var.txt:
FLOOR reports the main material of the floor of the household. This variable is based on the interviewer's observation, not the interviewee's response.
The type of floor found in the household is used to calculate a wealth index based on the household's cumulative living standard. This information can be found in the variables SCORE, WEALTHQ, and WEALTHT.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: EVERBIRTH
var.txt:
EVERBIRTH reports if the woman ever gave birth.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: BIRTHEVENT
var.txt:
BIRTHEVENT reports the total number of times the respondent has given live birth. It does not include births of stillborn children.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
Users may also be interested in CHEB, which reports the woman's response to the question "How many sons and daughters have you given birth to who were born alive?". The key distinction between BIRTHEVENT and CHEB is that multiple children could be born during one birth event.

var.name: KID1STBIRTHMO
var.txt:
KID1STBIRTHMO reports the month of the woman's first live birth.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year for her youngest child's date of birth, but not a month, January is the default month for KID1STBIRTHMO.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: KID1STBIRTHYR
var.txt:
KID1STBIRTHYR reports the year of the woman's first live birth.
Until 2020 samples, enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS-PMA has recoded these cases to "No response or missing." Additionally, IPUMS-PMA has recoded years that were in the future at the time of the interview as "Logical edit - missing." For example, values of 2018 or later in samples from 2016 have been recoded. For some samples, interviews were conducted across two years, for example, some 2016 samples include interviews from early 2017. Starting in 2020, enumerators were instructed to enter the date as 2030 instead for no responses.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: KID1STBIRTHCMC
var.labl: First child birthdate in century month
var.txt:
KID1STBIRTHCMC reports the century month code (CMC) for the month and year of the woman's first live birth.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see KID1STBIRTHMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for her first live birth, January was the default month. Also due to the data entry format, if a woman skipped the question, the default date was January 1st, 2021. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response." Additionally, IPUMS-PMA has recoded years that were in the future at the time of the interview as "Logical edit - missing." For example, values of 2018 or later in samples from 2016 have been recoded. For some samples, interviews were conducted across two years, for example, some 2016 samples include interviews from early 2017.
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result.
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: LASTBIRTHMO
var.labl: Month of most recent live birth
var.txt:
LASTBIRTHMO reports the month the woman's most recent child was born.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year for her most recent child's date of birth, but not a month, January is the default month for LASTBIRTHMO.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: LASTBIRTHYR
var.labl: Year of most recent live birth
var.txt:
LASTBIRTHYR reports the year the woman's most recent child was born.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response or missing". Additionally, IPUMS has recoded years that were in the future at the time of the interview as "Logical edit - missing". For example, values of 2018 or later in samples from 2016 have been recoded. For some samples, interviews were conducted across two years, for example, some 2016 samples include interviews from early 2017.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: LASTDOBCMC
var.labl: Birthdate of most recent child in century month
var.txt:
LASTDOBCMC reports the century month code (CMC) for the month and year of the birthdate of the woman's most recent child.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see LASTBIRTHMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for the birthdate of the woman's most recent child, January was the default month. Also due to the data entry format, if a woman skipped the question, the default date was January 1st, 2021. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA2020 occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result.
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FERTPREF
var.labl: Prefer to have another child or no more children
var.txt:
FERTPREF indicates whether or not the woman wanted to have a child (or another child) in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PGDESIRE
var.txt:
For currently pregnant women, PGDESIRE reports whether the woman's pregnancy was wanted at the time they got pregnant, was wanted but at a later time, or was not wanted at all.
Users may also be interested in FPLCHDESIRE. For women who are not currently pregnant but have ever given birth, this variable indicates whether their last born child was wanted at the time they got pregnant, was wanted but at a later time, or was not wanted at all.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health questionnaires, this question was included in the female screening questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Did not want pregnancy at all

var.name: FPLCHDESIRE
var.txt:
For women who are not currently pregnant but have ever given birth, FPLCHDESIRE reports whether their last born child was wanted at the time they got pregnant, was wanted but at a later time, or was not wanted at all.
Users may also be interested in PGDESIRE. For women who are currently pregnant, this variable indicates whether their pregnancy was wanted at the time they got pregnant, was wanted but at a later time, or was not wanted at all.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Did not want last child at all

var.name: PREFTIMECH
var.labl: How long would like to wait until next child
var.txt:
PREFTIMECH, together with PREFTIMECHVAL, reports the amount of time a woman would like to wait before the birth of a/another child. PREFTIMECH was constructed by combining PREFTIMECHPREG and PREFTIMECHNPREG.
Note that this variable reports only a specific unit of time i.e., months or years, not the actual duration of the interval. The specific number of months or years is reported in PREFTIMECHVAL. Users must use both PREFTIMECH and PREFTIMECHVAL to determine the exact amount of time the woman would like to wait before the birth of a child.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREFTIMECHVAL
var.labl: How long to wait - value if months or years
var.txt:
PREFTIMECHVAL reports the amount of time a woman would like to wait before the birth of a/another child. Values are reported in months or years. The variable must be used in combination with PREFTIMECH to determine the unit of measurement.
Enumerators were instructed to code the total number of months or years the woman would like to wait until a/another birth. However, in some samples, a select number of enumerators recorded specific years, e.g. 2017. We believe these cases were intended to represent the year in which the woman would like her next birth to occur. IPUMS-PMA previously recoded these cases to "Logical edit - missing." These cases now have been recoded by subtracting the year of the interview from the recorded response to estimate how long the women would like to wait until a/another birth.
There are some cases of valid values in PREFTIMECHVAL that do not correspond with either months or years in PREFTIMECH. These values occur in the original data and have not been edited by IPUMS.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FERTPREFNPREG
var.labl: Prefer to have another child or no more children - not pregnant
var.txt:
FERTPREFNPREG indicates whether or not the woman wanted to have a child (or another child) in the future. This variable contains responses for women who are not pregnant. A similar question was posed to women who were currently pregnant (FERTPREFPREG).
Users should note that there are a small number of cases of women in the universe for FERTPREFNPREG who are currently pregnant. It is not documented whether or not these cases are valid responses that should have been assigned to FERTPREFPREG.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FERTPREFPREG
var.labl: Prefer to have another child or no more children - currently pregnant
var.txt:
For women aged 15 to 49 who are currently pregnant, FERTPREFPREG indicates whether or not the woman wanted to have another child in the future. A similar question was posed to women who were not pregnant (FERTPREFNPREG).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREFTIMECHNPREG
var.labl: How long would like to wait until next child - not pregnant
var.txt:
For women who were not pregnant at the time of the interview, PREFTIMECHNPREG, together with PREFTIMECHVAL, reports the amount of time they would like to wait before the birth of a/another child.
Note that this variable reports only a specific unit of time i.e., months or years, not the actual duration of the interval. The specific number of months or years is reported in PREFTIMECHVAL. Users must use both PREFTIMECHNPREG and PREFTIMECHVAL to determine the exact amount of time the woman would like to wait before the birth of another child.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREFTIMECHPREG
var.labl: How long would like to wait until next child - pregnant
var.txt:
For women who were pregnant at the time of the interview, PREFTIMECHPREG, together with PREFTIMECHVAL, reports the amount of time they would like to wait before the birth of another child.
Note that this variable reports only a specific unit of time i.e., months or years, not the actual duration of the interval. The specific number of months or years is reported in PREFTIMECHVAL. Users must use both PREFTIMECHPREG and PREFTIMECHVAL to determine the exact amount of time the woman would like to wait before the birth of another child.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREGFEEL
var.labl: Level of happiness about current / recent pregnancy
var.txt:
PREGFEEL reports how happy the woman felt when she found out she was pregnant with her current pregnancy.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PREGFEELNOW
var.labl: Level of happiness if got pregnant now
var.txt:
PREGFEELNOW reports how happy the woman would feel if she got pregnant now.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: CP
var.txt:
CP indicates whether or not the woman is currently using any family planning method to delay or avoid becoming pregnant.
The values in CP are constructed from the variable FPCURREFFMETH, which reports the most effective family planning method the woman is currently using. It is important to note that there may be instances in which women who did not report current use of a contraceptive method (and are thus coded as "NIU (not in universe)" in FPCURREFFMETH) are coded as "Yes" in CP. Specifically, women who do not report current use of a contraceptive method are coded as "Yes" in CP if: a. they reported using emergency contraception in the last 12 months (FPEFFECTIVEYR)b. they reported female sterilization as their first contraceptive method (FP1STMETHOD)Users may also be interested in TCP and MCP, which indicate whether or not the woman is currently using a traditional contraceptive method and a modern contraceptive method, respectively.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: MCP
var.txt:
MCP indicates whether the woman is currently using a modern family planning method to delay or avoid becoming pregnant. PMA2020 considers sterilization, hormonal and barrier methods, emergency contraception, lactational amenorrhea method (LAM), and the standard days/cycle beads method to be modern methods of contraception.
In most cases MCP is derived from responses recorded in FPCURREFFMETH, which reports the most effective family planning method the woman is currently using. Women who do not report current use of a modern contraceptive method are coded as "Yes" in MCP if: a. they reported using emergency contraception in the last 12 months (FPEFFECTIVEYR)b. they reported female sterilization as their first contraceptive method (FP1STMETHOD)Additionally, women who report current use of the LAM must meet the following conditions to be coded as "Yes" in MCP: a. they must be less than six months post-partum (see LASTDOBCMC)b. they must be amenorrheic (not currently menstruating) (see TIMEMENSTRUATE and TIMEMENSTRUATEVAL)c. they must report that they are using LAM with the intention of avoiding or delaying a pregnancy (see FPNOWUSBF)If any of these conditions are not met, the woman is coded as "No" in MCP and "Yes" in TCP, which indicates whether the woman is currently using a traditional contraceptive method.
Users may also be interested in CP, which indicates whether or not the woman is currently using any contraceptive method.
The questions associated with this variable were included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: TCP
var.txt:
TCP indicates whether the woman is currently using a traditional family planning method to delay or avoid becoming pregnant. PMA considers the rhythm method and withdrawal to be traditional methods of contraception.
The values in TCP are constructed from the variable FPCURREFFMETH, which reports the most effective family planning method the woman is currently using. It is important to note that women who report current use of the lactational amenorrhea method (LAM) may be coded as "Yes" in TCP if they fail to meet any of the following conditions: a. they must be less than six months post-partum (see LASTDOBCMC)b. they must be amenorrheic (not currently menstruating) (see TIMEMENSTRUATE and TIMEMENSTRUATEVAL)c. they must report that they are using LAM with the intention of avoiding or delaying a pregnancy (see FPNOWUSBF)If all of these conditions are met, these women are coded as "No" in TCP and "Yes" in MCP, which indicates whether the woman is currently using a modern contraceptive method.
Users may also be interested in CP, which indicates whether or not the woman is currently using any contraceptive method.
The questions associated with this variable were included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPEVUSE
var.labl: Done anything to delay or avoid getting pregnant
var.txt:
FPEVUSE indicates whether the woman has ever used a method of family planning or done anything to delay or avoid getting pregnant.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Ever or First Use of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPBEGINUSEMO
var.labl: Month began using most recent or current method
var.txt:
FPBEGINUSEMO reports the month the woman first used her most recent or current family planning method. The instructions in the questionnaire specify that the respondent must have been at least 10 and at least the age she started using her first contraceptive method in the month and year that she reported.
Note that January consistently has the highest frequency across samples. Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she first used her most recent or current method, January is the default month for FPBEGINUSEMO.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response".
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPBEGINUSEYR
var.labl: Year began using most recent or current method
var.txt:
FPBEGINUSEYR reports the year the respondent first used her most recent or current family planning method. The instructions in the questionnaire specify that the respondent must have been at least 10 and at least the age she started using her first contraceptive method in the month and year that she reported.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response".
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPBEGINUSECMC
var.labl: Date first used most recent or current method in century month
var.txt:
FPBEGINUSECMC reports the century month code (CMC) for when the respondent first used her most recent or current family planning method. The instructions in the questionnaire specify that the respondent must have been at least 10 years old and at least the age she was when she started using her first contraceptive method in the month and year that she reported.
Note that January is consistently the most common month across samples (see FPBEGINUSEMO). Due to the data entry format of the survey, if a respondent reported a year but not a month for when she started using her most recent family planning method, January was the default month.
Enumerators were instructed to enter the date as January 1st, 2020 (January 1st, 2030 for samples in 2019 or after) if the respondent did not give a response to the associated survey question. IPUMS has recoded these cases to "No response."
Century month codes (CMC) are particularly useful for checking the consistency of dates, calculating intervals between events, and imputing dates when the information for an event is missing or partially complete.
Century month codes (CMC) are calculated by multiplying by 12 the difference between the year of an event and 1900. The year 1900 was chosen as the reference period because all of the relevant events for PMA occurred during the twentieth or twenty-first centuries. The month of the event is added to the previous result in the following formula:
CMC = (Year - 1900) * 12 + Month For example, the CMC for June 2002 is:
CMC = (2002 - 1900) * 12 + 6 = 1230
In other words, 1,230 months have elapsed between January 1900 and June 2002. Starting with CMC figures, one can calculate the month and year using the following formulas:
Year = int( ( CMC - 1 )/12 ) + 1900
[int(x) is the integer part of x]
Month = CMC - ( ( Year - 1900 ) * 12 )
The information above is based on "Online Guide to DHS Statistics" (Rutstein and Rojas, 2006).
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Current or Recent Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPAGE1STUSE
var.labl: Age at first use of FP
var.txt:
FPAGE1STUSE indicates the woman's self-reported age the time she first used a method of family planning.
FPAGE1STUSE has not been logically edited to remove unusually low values, which were present in the original data.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Ever or First Use of Family Planning Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPPLANWHEN
var.labl: When will start using FP method in the future
var.txt:
For women who are not currently using a family planning method but think they will use a method in the future, FPPLANWHEN reports when the woman thinks she will begin using the method.
Note that this variable reports only a specific unit of time, i.e. months or years, not the actual duration of the interval. The specific number of months or years is reported in FPPLANVAL. For women who reported they would wait months or years, users must use both FPPLANWHEN and FPPLANVAL to determine the exact amount of time that the woman thinks she will wait before beginning to use a family planning method.
Women who reported that they would begin using a method "soon / now" or "after the birth of this child" were not asked to report a value, and so are excluded from the universe of FPPLANVAL.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

catgry.labl: After the birth of this child

var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPPLANVAL
var.labl: When will start using FP method in the future- value
var.txt:
For women who are not currently using a family planning method but think they will use a method in the future, FPPLANVAL reports when the woman thinks she will begin using the method.
Note that the codes in this variable are not reported in a specific unit of time i.e., months, or years. Rather, the unit of time in which the woman responded is reported in FPPLANWHEN. For women who reported they would wait months or years, users must use both FPPLANVAL and FPPLANWHEN to determine the exact amount of time that the woman thinks she will wait before beginning to use a family planning method.
Note that some respondents reported a year, such as 2025 or 2030, instead of the number of years or months.
Women who reported that they would begin using a method "soon / now" or "after the birth of this child" were not asked to report a value, and so are excluded from this universe.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: LIVEINPLACE
var.labl: Number of years living continuously in current place of residence
var.txt:
For women aged 15-49, LIVEINPLACE reports the number of years living continuously in her current place of residence.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: LIVEINRES
var.labl: Number of years living continuously in current house / structure
var.txt:
LIVEINRES reports the number of years the woman has lived continuously in her current house / structure.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PLACECURMOVEAGE
var.labl: Age moved to current place of residence
var.txt:
PLACECURMOVEAGE is an IPUMS-calculated variable to estimate the age the woman moved to her current place of residence. Place of residence refers to the city, town, village, or neighborhood, not the structure of residence. PLACECURMOVEAGE is the difference between the woman's age (AGE) and how long she has continuously living in her current place of residence (LIVEINPLACE).
Note that this variable is a calculated field, and the values for some cases conflict with variables such as PLACE1MOVEAGE, in that PLACECURMOVEAGE is sometimes younger than ages reported for moving to previous residences. If LIVEINPLACE is greater than AGE, instead of a negative value, PLACECURMOVEAGE is recoded to zero.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: RESCURMOVEAGE
var.labl: Age moved to current house / structure
var.txt:
RESCURMOVEAGE is an IPUMS-calculated variable to estimate the age the woman moved to her current house or structure of residence. RESCURMOVEAGE is the difference between the woman's age (AGE) and how long she has continuously living in her current house or structure of residence (LIVEINRES).
Note that this variable is a calculated field, and the values for some cases conflict with variables such as PLACE1MOVEAGE, in that RESCURMOVEAGE is sometimes younger than ages reported for moving to previous residences. If LIVEINRES is greater than AGE, instead of a negative value, RESCURMOVEAGE is recoded to zero.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FPUSPLAN
var.labl: Plan to use a method in the future
var.txt:
For women who were not using a family planning method at the time of the interview or pregnant, FPUSPLAN indicates whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future. FPUSPLAN is a combination of the variables FPUSPLAN_PREG and FPUSPLAN_NPREG, which are divided based on the pregnancy status of the woman.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPUSPLAN_NPREG
var.labl: Plan to use a method in the future - not pregnant
var.txt:
For women who were not pregnant and not using a method of family planning at the time of the interview, FPUSPLAN_NPREG indicates whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future. The variable FPUSPLAN contains this information both for women who are currently pregnant and for women who are not pregnant.
Users may also be interested in FPUSPLAN_PREG, which indicates, for women who were pregnant at the time of the interview, whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: FPUSPLAN_PREG
var.labl: Plan to use a method in the future - currently pregnant
var.txt:
For women who were pregnant and not using a method of family planning at the time of the interview, FPUSPLAN_PREG indicates whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future. The variable FPUSPLAN contains this information both for women who are currently pregnant and for women who are not pregnant.
Users may also be interested in FPUSPLAN_NPREG, which indicates, for women who were not pregnant at the time of the interview, whether they think they will use a method of family planning to delay or avoid pregnancy in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
var.concept: Future Family Planning Use Variables -- PERSON

var.name: WORKWK
var.labl: Has done work other than own housework in last 7 days
var.txt:
WORKWK reports whether the woman has done any work aside from her own housework in the last 7 days. This includes work that is not paid and activities like work on the family farm or in the family business, selling things at the market, or running a small business.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: WORKYR
var.labl: Has done work other than own housework in last 12 months
var.txt:
For women who have not done any work outside their own housework in the last 7 days, WORKYR reports whether the woman has done any work aside from her own housework in the last 12 months. This includes work that is not paid and activities like work on the family farm or in the family business, selling things at the market, or running a small business.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHDECDAILY
var.labl: Who decides on daily household purchases
var.txt:
For women who are currently married or living with a male partner, HHDECDAILY reports who usually makes decisions about making household purchases for daily needs.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHDECMAJOR
var.labl: Who decides on large household purchases
var.txt:
For women who are currently married or living with a male partner, HHDECMAJOR reports who usually makes decisions about large household purchases.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHDECMED
var.txt:
For women who are currently married or living with a male partner, HHDECMED reports who usually makes decisions about getting medical treatment for the woman.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
